p.s: At the 7th April 2009 Barack Obama gave a short speech named Remarks of president Barack Obama at student roundtable on a visit to Istanbul, Turkey.

At the Culture and Arts Center of Mimar Sinan Fine Arts University in Tophane he gave the speech before the open discussion to the students about the importance of intercultural understanding and student exchanges.
The speech is divided into three parts.
The introduction, the main part and the end.
In the introduction he says why he came to Turkey and what he wants to do (ll. 1-3).
After revealing that he wants to rebuild a relationship between the United States and the people of the Muslim world, he begins with the main part.
In the main part he only points out positive aspects for his plan with the United States and the people of the Muslim world.

At first he points out that there is a new spirit of activism and responsibility and young people all around the world are passionate, engaged and deeply informed about the world and the people (ll. 4-8).
Therefore he tells about his plan to connect young people from America to other young people all around the world, so there is an international exchange (l. 9).
After telling his plan he litstlists the ways how he wants to connect the young people (ll. 10-11).

Next he points out another advantage of international exchange by telling about the mistrust that begins to fade and that our smaller differences no longer overshadow the things that we share (ll. 16-17).
At the end he reminds the students that we form our world and it lies in our hand (l. 18).
He says that we choose what we make with our world and with every prosperity and endeavour, there is a partner, supporter or a friend in the United States of America.
He says this, so the international students do not fear to come to the United States so they can help the world and make it to a better place.

All in all, it can be said that Barack Obama is really positive and motivated about his plan, because he only points out positive facts about his plan and there are a lot of argument about the importance of intercultural understanding and student exchanges.
The president Barack Obama useuses the pronouns I, me and we.
This shows the students, who are listening that they all are on the same boat and everybody, even Barack Obama, should have a good look at the importance of intercultural understanding.
At the end he speaks directly to the listeners by using the pronouns you, so that they listen more carefully and feel involved in the speech.
With the sentence That's always been a critical part of how America engages the world (l. 11), he shows that it is not only his interest but from the United States of America.
